problem:
The matrix
\[\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -1 \\ c & d \end{pmatrix}\]is its own inverse.  Enter the ordered pair $(c,d).$
solution:
Since $\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -1 \\ c & d \end{pmatrix}$ is its own inverse,
\[\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -1 \\ c & d \end{pmatrix}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -1 \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -1 \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} = \mathbf{I}.\]This gives us
\[\begin{pmatrix} 9 - c & -d - 3 \\ cd + 3c & d^2 - c \end{pmatrix} = \mathbf{I}.\]Then $9 - c = 1,$ $-d - 3 = 0,$ $cd + 3c = 0,$ and $d^2 - c = 1.$  Solving, we find $(c,d) = \boxed{(8,-3)}.$
model_solution:
If the matrix
\[\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -1 \\ c & d \end{pmatrix}\]is its own inverse, then

\[\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -1 \\ c & d \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -1 \\ c & d \end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\]

Multiplying both sides, we have

\[\begin{pmatrix} 3\cdot3+(-1)c & 3\cdot(-1)+(-1)d \\ c\cdot3+d\cdot c & c\cdot(-1)+d\cdot d \end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\]

This simplifies to

\[\begin{pmatrix} 9-c & -3-d \\ 3c+dc & -c+d^2 \end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\]

Equating the entries, we have the following system of equations:

\begin{align*}
9-c&=1\\
-3-d&=0\\
3c+dc&=0\\
-c+d^2&=1
\end{align*}

Solving the first equation for $c$, we have $c=8$.  Substituting this into the third equation and solving for $d$, we have

\begin{align*}
3c+dc&=0\\
\Rightarrow\qquad 3\cdot 8+8d&=0\\
\Rightarrow\qquad 24+8d&=0\\
\Rightarrow\qquad 8d&=-24\\
\Rightarrow\qquad d&=-24/8\\
\Rightarrow\qquad d&=-3
\end{align*}

Therefore, we have $c=8$ and $d=-3$.  Hence, the ordered pair is $(c,d)=\boxed{(8,-3)}$.
